Table 1 provides the properties of selected datasets in terms of their size, task and evaluation metric. For more details of these datasets, we refer the readers to the original papers. We make use of the official split provided for each dataset.
We follow the task processing, reformulation and data split as outlined in the DUE benchmark [1] to make all the tasks aligned with the DU paradigm. Particularly, we unify all training data into the triplet (document image, question, answer) format. In addition, annotations are partly inherited from DUE, including: document image, question/answer, OCR tokens, while the normalized bounding boxes are generated the same way as in [39].

Effect of number of communication rounds Tğ‘‡T.
Similarly, we investigate the impact of Tğ‘‡T for both FSP and DocVQA federated training. First, we run experiments having upto 25 rounds of communication with the FedAvg baseline. In another set of experiments, we run FSP with varying number of Tğ‘‡T while fixing this value for finetuning to 10. This choice is made because FSP is less computationally intensive than DocVQA, provided that training data size for FSP is significantly smaller compared to DocVQA, as indicated in Table 1.

Table 6: FedAvgM and FedAdam Test set performance on different configurations of (K,C)ğ¾ğ¶(K,C). The rightmost column shows the baselineâ€™s performance.



From Figure 5 (right), there is a substantial improvement while increasing the communication rounds Tğ‘‡T to 10 in FSP, with further increases resulting in only marginal improvements. A similar trend is also noticed in Figure 5 (left) as the finetuning round Tğ‘‡T increases.
We hypothesize that in the early stages of training, the drift in local updates prevents the model from learning effectively.
This necessitates a much longer period to achieve convergence, therefore increasing the overall cost of training. Based on these results, for our next experiments we opt to fix T=10ğ‘‡10T=10, which strikes a good balance between communication efficiency and DocVQA performance.

In FeDocVQA, we assume that the training examples of each client are disjoint subsets of documents from one single dataset. To synthesize a population of non-identical Kğ¾K clients, for each dataset Ddâ€‹oâ€‹câˆˆ{DWâ€‹Tâ€‹Q;DDâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹Vâ€‹Qâ€‹A;DTâ€‹aâ€‹bâ€‹Fâ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹t}subscriptğ·ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘subscriptğ·ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘„subscriptğ·ğ·ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘„ğ´subscriptğ·ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡D_{doc}\in\{D_{WTQ};D_{DocVQA};D_{TabFact}\}, we evenly distribute documents into kdâ€‹oâ€‹câˆˆ{kWâ€‹Tâ€‹Q;kDâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹Vâ€‹Qâ€‹A;kTâ€‹aâ€‹bâ€‹Fâ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹t}subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘„subscriptğ‘˜ğ·ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘„ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡k_{doc}\in\{k_{WTQ};k_{DocVQA};k_{TabFact}\} clients by random sampling without replacement, such that kWâ€‹Tâ€‹Q+kDâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹Vâ€‹Qâ€‹A+kTâ€‹aâ€‹bâ€‹Fâ€‹aâ€‹câ€‹t=Ksubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘„subscriptğ‘˜ğ·ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘„ğ´subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ¾k_{WTQ}+k_{DocVQA}+k_{TabFact}=K. This strategy creates a balanced population among clients which receive the data from the same source, while ensures the data in every client unique. We consider 3 FL scenarios, which correspond to having Kâˆˆ{3;10;30}ğ¾31030K\in\{3;10;30\} clients. K=3ğ¾3K=3 signifies each client holds one entire original dataset, which is highly representative of real-world FL scenarios, whereas K=30ğ¾30K=30 scales the problem with a high number of participating clients that each has access to a much smaller number of samples.
Table 2 illustrates data populations resulted from our partitioning scheme and its statistics.

We first analyze the result with different values of Kğ¾K. We observe a significantly lower performance when K=3ğ¾3K=3 and C=0.35ğ¶0.35C=0.35, corresponding to fine-tuning the model on one dataset after another, leading to catastrophic forgetting. It can also be seen from Figure 4 and Figure 4 that the validation loss/per-dataset metric fluctuates considerably at each round.
Interestingly, increasing in the number of clients Kğ¾K from 3 to 10 yields substantial improvements, but further increasing from 10 to 30 results in a decline in performance. For instance, considering C=0.35ğ¶0.35C=0.35, increasing Kğ¾K from 3 to 10 highlights the advantages of FL, as the server aggregates training updates from multiple clients, therefore mitigating heterogeneity in each communication round. However, the performance drop observed when increasing Kğ¾K from 10 to 30 is attributed to significantly less local computation and more frequent model synchronization. Specifically, recall from Table 2, when K=10ğ¾10K=10, each client holds 2x-4x more data compared to when K=30ğ¾30K=30, allowing for more gradient steps during local training and less frequent weight synchronization. In contrast, K=30ğ¾30K=30 entails a more widely spread population with less training data per client. This observation suggests that having more local updates per round can speedup convergence and result in better performance, aligning with prior research findings [28]. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the partition is synthetically created, thus the final performance is sensitive on the client-to-dataset ratio, which is computed based on the size of each dataset.

Table 4 summarizes FeDocVQA performance of FedAvg as a function of number of total clients Kğ¾K and sampling probability Cğ¶C. Plots of validation performances (loss/metric) for the case K=3ğ¾3K=3 are in Figure 4.
We also present results for (C=1,K=1)formulae-sequenceğ¶1ğ¾1(C=1,K=1), which corresponds to the centralized training, where the model is finetuned using data from all datasets collectively. Compared to the T5-large variant [1], simply finetuning our model already achieves comparable performance with fewer parameters (220M vs 770M).

Effect of FSP. The purpose of FSP is to provide a warm start to the PLM, allowing it to better adapt to document data. In Table 4, we compare the performance of FedAvg with various pretraining objectives. As expected, each pretraining objective improves the results compared to the baseline. When all objectives are combined, FSP achieves a great improvement in FeDocVQA, outperforming the baseline by approximately 2.6 points while solely utilizing private data, which is considerably smaller in size compared to common practices. We believe our FSP strategy can effectively scale up with more documents while maintaining a high level of client data privacy. We utilize all pretraining tasks in our subsequent experiments.

Table 4 summarizes FeDocVQA performance of FedAvg as a function of number of total clients Kğ¾K and sampling probability Cğ¶C. Plots of validation performances (loss/metric) for the case K=3ğ¾3K=3 are in Figure 4.
We also present results for (C=1,K=1)formulae-sequenceğ¶1ğ¾1(C=1,K=1), which corresponds to the centralized training, where the model is finetuned using data from all datasets collectively. Compared to the T5-large variant [1], simply finetuning our model already achieves comparable performance with fewer parameters (220M vs 770M).

Effect of FSP. The purpose of FSP is to provide a warm start to the PLM, allowing it to better adapt to document data. In Table 4, we compare the performance of FedAvg with various pretraining objectives. As expected, each pretraining objective improves the results compared to the baseline. When all objectives are combined, FSP achieves a great improvement in FeDocVQA, outperforming the baseline by approximately 2.6 points while solely utilizing private data, which is considerably smaller in size compared to common practices. We believe our FSP strategy can effectively scale up with more documents while maintaining a high level of client data privacy. We utilize all pretraining tasks in our subsequent experiments.

Effect of Client fraction Cğ¶C. We also study the effect of the Cğ¶C for each round during pretraining/finetuning, denoted as Cptsubscriptğ¶ptC_{\text{pt}} and Cftsubscriptğ¶ftC_{\text{ft}} respectively. Table 5 gives results for each value pair of (Cpt,Cft)subscriptğ¶ptsubscriptğ¶ft(C_{\text{pt}},C_{\text{ft}}), both in {0.35;0.7;1}0.350.71\{0.35;0.7;1\}. First, we see that for each Cftsubscriptğ¶ftC_{\text{ft}} value, there is at least one configuration (Cpt,Cft)subscriptğ¶ptsubscriptğ¶ft(C_{\text{pt}},C_{\text{ft}}) that outperforms the FedAvg baseline (compare numbers in each row). This demonstrates the consistent effectiveness of FSP across varying numbers of clients participating in each round. This result holds especially when Cptsubscriptğ¶ptC_{\text{pt}} and Cftsubscriptğ¶ftC_{\text{ft}} have the same value, implying that maintaining a consistent parallelism between the two training phases is beneficial. In our subsequent experiments, we employ the same values for both Cptsubscriptğ¶ptC_{\text{pt}} and Cftsubscriptğ¶ftC_{\text{ft}}.

Table 7 presents our main results over our set of proposed methods and experiments. We select the best results, based on the hyperparameters selected for ablation study, for each configuration (K,C)ğ¾ğ¶(K,C). Overall, our FSP strategy is beneficial for DocVQA under FL with consistent improvements across different configurations. While FedAvg can still be effective for small-scale setting like K=3ğ¾3K=3, FedAdam is considered the better design choice in a more heterogeneous system like K=10ğ¾10K=10.
